awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Squeezing the Optical Frequency Comb: Applications to Quantum Computing  and Quantum Measurement
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum computing is a powerful concept with revolutionary scientific discovery potential. Computing with quantum bits, known as "qubits," as initially envisioned by Richard Feynman, would allow physicists to solve problems traditionally far out of reach, such as the ab initio design of new materials (e.g. room-temperature superconductors), new chemical reactions (for fertilizer production, or for carbon sequestration), and new drugs (for medicine) based on the principles of quantum physics. Two fundamental requirements for building a practical and useful quantum computer are: (i), access to a large number of individually addressable qubits and, (ii), the ability to eschew qubit errors and, if not, to correct them.  This project will address both of these requirements by exploring new ways to use quantum states of light to encode information.  This approach will train students to develop optics and photonics technologies.  It will also promote fundamental scientific collaborations via the NSF-BSF program. 

The aim of this project is the implementation of a quantum processor using a multitude of laser beams with different frequencies called "qumodes" that are specifically engineered to display the quantum correlations, or entanglement, needed to run quantum algorithms. The quantum optics group at the  University  of Virginia has been pioneering such an approach and has obtained a record number of entangled qumodes. This project will promote a collaboration with Bar-Ilan University that will expand the scope of this research by developing a novel detection method for qumodes.  This collaboration will also address quantum error correction by using quantum optics to develop new detection techniques that are resilient to optical losses and noise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF PHY-1820882 grant, "NSF-BSF: Squeezing the Optical Frequency Comb: Applications to Quantum Computing and Quantum Measurement,"supported the international collaboration of Prof. Olivier Pfister at the University of Virginia and Prof. Avi Pe'er at Bar-Ilan University. A number of fundamental results, both theoretical and experimental, were obtained under this award, all of which paving the way to the experimental realization of photonic quantum computing. 

The main collaboration result was theoretical: a fundamental method to generate the exotic light that could be used as an optical, i.e., photonic, quantum computer. In this model, different colors of light play the role of different qubits. When considering a quantum computing platform, both the wave-like and particle-like aspects of quantum physics must be equally weighted. Here, the frequency (color) of the electromagnetic waves that constitute light define the qubits and the photon correlations of the light define the entanglement between qubits, which one can consider as the engine of a quantum computer. 

One particularly powerful aspect of photonic quantum computing is the PIs’ proven experimental ability to discern very close shades of light color, i.e., optical frequencies, which directly results in a large number of qubits, emitted by a single light source, an analog of the laser called the optical parametric oscillator (OPO). The main difference between an OPO and a laser is that light emission proceeds by photon pairs rather than photon by photon. This exotic property yields photon correlations between different light colors, which has been shown to translate into quantum entanglement between qubits. It has been shown that generating specific types of entangled states in a qubit quantum computing register, called cluster states, can activate the universal set of quantum computing gates solely by single-qubit measurement and feedforward operations. The work by Pfister and Pe’er showed that simple, well-known photonics tools such as an OPO followed by an optical phase modulator are all what’s needed to generate sophisticated cluster states over linear, square, cubic, and hypercubic entanglement lattices [1]. Other fundamental results by the Pfister group led to the first complete theoretical understanding of the cluster states emitted by OPOs [2]. 

On the experimental side, this project pursued the particle nature of light, which is harder to directly access/observe as it requires photon-number-resolving (PNR) detectors. Thanks to a previous NSF MRI award (PHY- 0960047), the Pfister group is equipped with a PNR detector system: transition edge sensors (TES) built by the group of the late SaeWoo Nam at NIST. Using TES detection, The Pfister group discovered a new method for performing quantum state tomography using PNR measurements: generalized overlap tomography [3]. This method is one of the most resource-efficient quantum state estimation techniques to date and was demonstrated experimentally on the Wigner function reconstruction of a single-photon state.

Last but not least, the PNR capability was extended to the detection of up to 100 photons, a remarkable near-mesoscopic regime, while retaining single-photon resolution in the counting. This was applied to the quantum generation of unbiased random numbers, in collaboration with Prof. Chris Gerry at CUNY Lehman College and Drs. Paul Alsing and Rich Birrittella at AFRL, for the theoretical side [4].

REFERENCES

[1]       X. Zhu, C.-H. Chang, C. González-Arciniegas, A. Pe’er, J. Higgins, and O. Pfister, "Hypercubic cluster states in the phase-modulated quantum optical frequency comb," Optica, vol. 8, no. 3, pp. 281–290, Mar. 2021, doi: 10.1364/OPTICA.411713.

[2]       C. González-Arciniegas, P. Nussenzveig, M. Martinelli, and O. Pfister, "Cluster states from gaussian states: Essential diagnostic tools for continuous-variable one-way quantum computing," PRX Quantum, vol. 2, no. 3, p. 030343, Sep. 2021, doi: 10.1103/PRXQuantum.2.030343.

[3]       R. Nehra et al., "Generalized overlap quantum state tomography," Phys. Rev. Res., vol. 2, no. 4, p. 042002, Oct. 2020, doi: 10.1103/PhysRevResearch.2.042002.

[4]       M. Eaton et al., "Resolution of 100 photons and quantum generation of unbiased random numbers," Nat. Photonics, Dec. 2022, doi: 10.1038/s41566-022-01105-9.
